questions.question: What is the difference between descriptive and inferential statistics?
options: Descriptive is harder than inferential
Descriptive summarizes data; inferential makes predictions about populations from samples
They are the same thing
Descriptive is for large datasets; inferential is for small datasets
questions.explanation: Descriptive statistics summarize and describe data using measures like mean, median, mode, standard deviation, and visualizations (charts, graphs). Inferential statistics use sample data to make inferences, predictions, or generalizations about a larger population using hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and regression. Example: Calculating average class test score is descriptive; predicting population average from a sample is inferential.

questions.question: What is the difference between mean, median, and mode?
options: They all measure the same thing
Mean is average, median is middle value, mode is most frequent value
Mean is for text, median is for numbers, mode is for dates
Median is always larger than mean
questions.explanation: Mean is the arithmetic average (sum of all values divided by count). Median is the middle value when data is sorted (50th percentile). Mode is the most frequently occurring value. For symmetric distributions, they're similar. For skewed data: in right-skewed distributions, mean > median > mode; in left-skewed, mode > median > mean. Median is robust to outliers, while mean is sensitive to them.

questions.question: What is standard deviation?
options: The average of all values
A measure of the spread or dispersion of data around the mean
The middle value in a dataset
The most frequent value
questions.explanation: Standard deviation (σ or s) measures how spread out data is from the mean. Low standard deviation means data points are close to the mean (less variability); high standard deviation means data is more dispersed. It's calculated as the square root of variance. In a normal distribution, about 68% of data falls within 1 standard deviation, 95% within 2, and 99.7% within 3 (empirical rule).

questions.question: What is a normal distribution?
options: Any distribution of data
A bell-shaped, symmetric probability distribution where most data clusters around the mean
A distribution with outliers
A uniform distribution
questions.explanation: A normal distribution (Gaussian distribution) is a symmetric, bell-shaped probability distribution characterized by its mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ). Most values cluster around the mean, with probabilities tapering off symmetrically on both sides. Many natural phenomena follow normal distributions (heights, test scores, measurement errors). The Central Limit Theorem states that sample means tend toward normal distribution regardless of the population distribution.

questions.question: What is correlation?
options: When two variables cause each other
A statistical measure of the relationship between two variables (-1 to +1)
The average of two variables
The difference between two variables
questions.explanation: Correlation measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables, ranging from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation), with 0 indicating no linear relationship. Positive correlation: both variables increase together; negative correlation: one increases as the other decreases. Important: correlation does not imply causation. Pearson's r is most common; Spearman's rank for non-linear relationships.

questions.question: What is a p-value in hypothesis testing?
options: The probability that a hypothesis is true
The probability of observing the data (or more extreme) if the null hypothesis is true
The average value in a dataset
The percentage of correct predictions
questions.explanation: A p-value is the probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as those observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true. Low p-value (typically < 0.05) suggests strong evidence against the null hypothesis, leading to its rejection. Example: p-value of 0.03 means there's a 3% probability of observing this data if there's truly no effect. Common misconception: p-value is NOT the probability that the null hypothesis is true.

questions.question: What is the difference between population and sample?
options: Population is people; sample is data
Population is the entire group of interest; sample is a subset used for analysis
Sample is always larger than population
They mean the same thing
questions.explanation: A population is the complete set of all items or individuals of interest in a study. A sample is a subset of the population selected for analysis. Example: All US voters (population) vs. 1,000 voters polled (sample). We use samples because analyzing entire populations is often impractical or impossible. Sample statistics (x̄, s) estimate population parameters (μ, σ). Representative sampling is crucial for valid inferences.

questions.question: What is variance?
options: The average of a dataset
The average of squared deviations from the mean, measuring data spread
The most common value
The middle value
questions.explanation: Variance (σ² or s²) measures the average squared deviation from the mean, quantifying data spread or variability. It's calculated by taking each data point's deviation from the mean, squaring it, and averaging these squared deviations. Higher variance indicates more spread. Standard deviation is the square root of variance, making it more interpretable (same units as original data). Variance is fundamental in statistics and machine learning.

questions.question: What is a confidence interval?
options: The range of all possible values in a dataset
A range of values likely to contain the true population parameter with a specified probability
The difference between maximum and minimum values
The average plus or minus one
questions.explanation: A confidence interval provides a range of values, calculated from sample data, likely to contain the true population parameter (e.g., mean). A 95% confidence interval means if we repeated the sampling process many times, 95% of the calculated intervals would contain the true parameter. Example: 'We're 95% confident the population mean is between 45 and 55.' Wider intervals indicate more uncertainty; larger samples produce narrower intervals.

questions.question: What is the Central Limit Theorem?
options: Data always forms a bell curve
The sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches normal distribution as sample size increases, regardless of population distribution
All statistics must be calculated from the center
Large datasets are more accurate
questions.explanation: The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) states that as sample size increases, the distribution of sample means approaches a normal distribution, regardless of the population's original distribution shape. This is fundamental because it allows us to make inferences using normal distribution theory even when the underlying population isn't normal. Typically, samples of n ≥ 30 are considered sufficient for CLT to apply. This justifies many statistical procedures.
